subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit And Larger Scale Tests
msgSnippet: I ve used JUnit for system testing as well as unit testing. It worked pretty well -- JUnit has great tool support, is small and simple and, being plain old
messageBody:
I've used JUnit for system testing as well as unit testing.

It worked pretty well -- JUnit has great tool support, is small and
simple and, being plain old Java, is easy to extend or plug onto
existing APIs and external systems.

The two main drawbacks we found were:

1) Too hard to go back and find out about the system behaviour from
the tests. We refactored our tests agressively into a "domain
specific embedded language" for describing business rules, but it was
difficult to find the test(s) we needed to read to understand why the
system did what it did.

2) A JUnit test aborts completely on failure. For system tests, we
wanted to distinguish between fatal failures that should abort the
test, and failures that allowed the test to continue running. For
example, a system that displays calculations in a table should fail
the test if any calculations are incorrect and report *all* the
incorrect calculations, not abort as soon as it detects a single
incorrect calculation.

FIT and similar tools address these issues much better than JUnit, but
you sacrifice easy refactoring.

--Nat

2008/9/8 Jan Kroeze <thejcwk@...>:
> Hi!
>
> Very good point about acceptance testing and system boundaries. I hadn't
> thought of this and people often forget to mention it. Of course, this has a
> great effect on the tools you end up using.
>
> Also, I agree regarding the combinatorial explosion problem. I had to write
> a Lexer for a toy programming language in one of my courses and having a
> unit test for each input pattern helped to narrow down problems so quickly
> that I finished in ~3 hours!
>
> People here at varsity also seldom miss the point about testing scope. They
> seem to assume that every level of testing will always be used, and teach
> accordingly. I think it's important to note that this is not always
> neccessary.
>
> Thanks for the distinction you made between integration tests and larger
> scale ones. I think I understand a little better where the boundaries lie :)
>
> 2008/9/4 lancezant <lancezant@...>
>
>> Hi Jan,
>>
>> I agree, and as you touch on the idea of acceptance tests, you come
>> close to the one point I'd add. Besides running time and number of
>> failures, the other distinguishing feature of acceptance tests is that
>> the interacts often cross the system's boundary. By that I mean input
>> comes through non-java interfaces such as GUIs, message systems, etc.
>> and output involve more side effects (i.e. go to places other than
>> back to the source). In some cases, these can be shoehorned into a
>> Java interface (e.g. httpunit) but this is often where the need for
>> other tools comes in.
>>
>> The reason for fine-grained testing is that large-grained tests are
>> overwhelmed by combinatoric explosion of conditions long before they
>> achieve reasonable coverage. The "unit" is usually a single class.
>> The system can be tens to thousands of classes. For small systems,
>> the gap may be small enough that unit and acceptance tests are
>> sufficient.
>>
>> Often, however, it is useful to have integration tests in between. By
>> testing clusters of collaborating classes, integration tests can
>> further reduce the number of acceptance tests needed to achieve
>> reasonable coverage. The thing integration tests have in common with
>> unit tests is that by being entirely within the system boundary, they
>> can reuse much of the Java infrastructure, including JUnit, mock
>> objects, etc.
>>
>> Best regards,
>> Lance
>>
>>

>> > > Jan,
>> > >
>> > > You can use JUnit for longer-running tests, but there are some
>> assumptions
>> > > JUnit embodies that will cause some problems. JUnit assumes tests
>> are
>> > > atomic--they run or don't run, they run in unit time. Integration
>> tests
>> > > often take a long time to run, so interim feedback is valuable.
>> Integration
>> > > tests can usefully have multiple failures, where that is less
>> common with
>> > > unit tests. OTOH, tests are tests--independent self-checking bits
>> of code
>> > > that run and get reported--and for that part of running
>> integration tests
>> > > JUnit works fine.
>> > >
>> > > It seems to me to be a tradeoff between the simplicity of running
>> all tests
>> > > as JUnit tests and the challenges of getting the integration tests
>> to run
>> > > as
>> > > JUnit tests. Different contexts will requires different solutions.
>> If I had
>> > > a few integration tests, I'd make them work with JUnit. If I had a
>> large
>> > > suite of integration tests that played a prominent role in
>> development, I
>> > > would use some other tool and integrate my unit testing results
>> with the
>> > > integration results.
>> > >
